speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: SCENE III. Wales. Before Flint castle.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter, with drum and colours, HENRY BOLINGBROKE, DUKE OF YORK, NORTHUMBERLAND, Attendants, and forces

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: So that by this intelligence we learn

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The Welshmen are dispersed, and Salisbury

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Is gone to meet the king, who lately landed

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: With some few private friends upon this coast.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The news is very fair and good, my lord:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Richard not far from hence hath hid his head.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: It would beseem the Lord Northumberland

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: To say 'King Richard:' alack the heavy day

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: When such a sacred king should hide his head.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Your grace mistakes; only to be brief

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Left I his title out.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The time hath been,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Would you have been so brief with him, he would

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Have been so brief with you, to shorten you,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: For taking so the head, your whole head's length.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Mistake not, uncle, further than you should.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Take not, good cousin, further than you should.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Lest you mistake the heavens are o'er our heads.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I know it, uncle, and oppose not myself

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Against their will. But who comes here?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Enter HENRY PERCY

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Welcome, Harry: what, will not this castle yield?

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: The castle royally is mann'd, my lord,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Against thy entrance.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Royally!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Why, it contains no king?

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Yes, my good lord,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: It doth contain a king; King Richard lies

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Within the limits of yon lime and stone:

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: And with him are the Lord Aumerle, Lord Salisbury,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Sir Stephen Scroop, besides a clergyman

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Of holy reverence; who, I cannot learn.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: O, belike it is the Bishop of Carlisle.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Noble lords,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Go to the rude ribs of that ancient castle;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Through brazen trumpet send the breath of parley

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Into his ruin'd ears, and thus deliver:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Henry Bolingbroke

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: On both his knees doth kiss King Richard's hand

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And sends allegiance and true faith of heart

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To his most royal person, hither come

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Even at his feet to lay my arms and power,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Provided that my banishment repeal'd

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And lands restored again be freely granted:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: If not, I'll use the advantage of my power

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And lay the summer's dust with showers of blood

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Rain'd from the wounds of slaughter'd Englishmen:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The which, how far off from the mind of Bolingbroke

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: It is, such crimson tempest should bedrench

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The fresh green lap of fair King Richard's land,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My stooping duty tenderly shall show.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Go, signify as much, while here we march

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Upon the grassy carpet of this plain.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Let's march without the noise of threatening drum,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: That from this castle's tatter'd battlements

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Our fair appointments may be well perused.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Methinks King Richard and myself should meet

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: With no less terror than the elements

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Of fire and water, when their thundering shock

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: At meeting tears the cloudy cheeks of heaven.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Be he the fire, I'll be the yielding water:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The rage be his, whilst on the earth I rain

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My waters; on the earth, and not on him.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: March on, and mark King Richard how he looks.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Parle without, and answer within. Then a flourish.  Enter on the walls, KING RICHARD II, the BISHOP OF  CARLISLE, DUKE OF AUMERLE, SIR STEPHEN SCROOP, and EARL OF SALISBURY

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: See, see, King Richard doth himself appear,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: As doth the blushing discontented sun

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: From out the fiery portal of the east,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: When he perceives the envious clouds are bent

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To dim his glory and to stain the track

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Of his bright passage to the occident.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Yet looks he like a king: behold, his eye,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: As bright as is the eagle's, lightens forth

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Controlling majesty: alack, alack, for woe,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: That any harm should stain so fair a show!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We are amazed; and thus long have we stood

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To watch the fearful bending of thy knee,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To NORTHUMBERLAND

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Because we thought ourself thy lawful king:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And if we be, how dare thy joints forget

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To pay their awful duty to our presence?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: If we be not, show us the hand of God

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That hath dismissed us from our stewardship;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For well we know, no hand of blood and bone

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Can gripe the sacred handle of our sceptre,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Unless he do profane, steal, or usurp.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And though you think that all, as you have done,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Have torn their souls by turning them from us,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And we are barren and bereft of friends;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Yet know, my master, God omnipotent,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Is mustering in his clouds on our behalf

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Armies of pestilence; and they shall strike

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Your children yet unborn and unbegot,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That lift your vassal hands against my head

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And threat the glory of my precious crown.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Tell Bolingbroke--for yond methinks he stands--

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That every stride he makes upon my land

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Is dangerous treason: he is come to open

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The purple testament of bleeding war;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But ere the crown he looks for live in peace,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Ten thousand bloody crowns of mothers' sons

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Shall ill become the flower of England's face,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Change the complexion of her maid-pale peace

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To scarlet indignation and bedew

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Her pastures' grass with faithful English blood.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The king of heaven forbid our lord the king

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Should so with civil and uncivil arms

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Be rush'd upon! Thy thrice noble cousin

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Harry Bolingbroke doth humbly kiss thy hand;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And by the honourable tomb he swears,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: That stands upon your royal grandsire's bones,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And by the royalties of both your bloods,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Currents that spring from one most gracious head,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And by the buried hand of warlike Gaunt,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And by the worth and honour of himself,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Comprising all that may be sworn or said,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: His coming hither hath no further scope

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Than for his lineal royalties and to beg

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Enfranchisement immediate on his kn ees:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Which on thy royal party granted once,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: His glittering arms he will commend to rust,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: His barbed steeds to stables, and his heart

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: To faithful service of your majesty.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: This swears he, as he is a prince, is just;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And, as I am a gentleman, I credit him.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Northumberland, say thus the king returns:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: His noble cousin is right welcome hither;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And all the number of his fair demands

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Shall be accomplish'd without contradiction:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With all the gracious utterance thou hast

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Speak to his gentle hearing kind commends.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We do debase ourselves, cousin, do we not,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To DUKE OF AUMERLE

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To look so poorly and to speak so fair?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Shall we call back Northumberland, and send

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Defiance to the traitor, and so die?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: No, good my lord; let's fight with gentle words

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Till time lend friends and friends their helpful swords.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: O God, O God! that e'er this tongue of mine,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That laid the sentence of dread banishment

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: On yon proud man, should take it off again

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With words of sooth! O that I were as great

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As is my grief, or lesser than my name!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Or that I could forget what I have been,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Or not remember what I must be now!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Swell'st thou, proud heart? I'll give thee scope to beat,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Since foes have scope to beat both thee and me.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Northumberland comes back from Bolingbroke.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What must the king do now? must he submit?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The king shall do it: must he be deposed?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The king shall be contented: must he lose

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The name of king? o' God's name, let it go:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I'll give my jewels for a set of beads,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My gorgeous palace for a hermitage,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My gay apparel for an almsman's gown,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My figured goblets for a dish of wood,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My sceptre for a palmer's walking staff,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My subjects for a pair of carved saints

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And my large kingdom for a little grave,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: A little little grave, an obscure grave;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Or I'll be buried in the king's highway,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Some way of common trade, where subjects' feet

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: May hourly trample on their sovereign's head;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For on my heart they tread now whilst I live;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And buried once, why not upon my head?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Aumerle, thou weep'st, my tender-hearted cousin!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We'll make foul weather with despised tears;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Our sighs and they shall lodge the summer corn,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And make a dearth in this revolting land.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Or shall we play the wantons with our woes,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And make some pretty match with shedding tears?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As thus, to drop them still upon one place,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Till they have fretted us a pair of graves

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Within the earth; and, therein laid,--there lies

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Two kinsmen digg'd their graves with weeping eyes.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Would not this ill do well? Well, well, I see

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I talk but idly, and you laugh at me.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Most mighty prince, my Lord Northumberland,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What says King Bolingbroke? will his majesty

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Give Richard leave to live till Richard die?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: You make a leg, and Bolingbroke says ay.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: My lord, in the base court he doth attend

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: To speak with you; may it please you to come down.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Down, down I come; like glistering Phaethon,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Wanting the manage of unruly jades.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: In the base court? Base court, where kings grow base,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To come at traitors' calls and do them grace.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: In the base court? Come down? Down, court!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: down, king!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For night-owls shriek where mounting larks

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: should sing.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Exeunt from above

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: What says his majesty?

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Sorrow and grief of heart

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Makes him speak fondly, like a frantic man

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Yet he is come.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Enter KING RICHARD and his attendants below

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Stand all apart,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And show fair duty to his majesty.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: He kneels down

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My gracious lord,--

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Fair cousin, you debase your princely knee

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To make the base earth proud with kissing it:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Me rather had my heart might feel your love

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Than my unpleased eye see your courtesy.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Up, cousin, up; your heart is up, I know,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thus high at least, although your knee be low.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My gracious lord, I come but for mine own.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Your own is yours, and I am yours, and all.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: So far be mine, my most redoubted lord,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: As my true service shall deserve your love.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Well you deserve: they well deserve to have,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That know the strong'st and surest way to get.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Uncle, give me your hands: nay, dry your eyes;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Tears show their love, but want their remedies.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Cousin, I am too young to be your father,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Though you are old enough to be my heir.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What you will have, I'll give, and willing too;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For do we must what force will have us do.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Set on towards London, cousin, is it so?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Yea, my good lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Then I must not say no.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Flourish. Exeunt
